Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Vlasov Multi-Dimensional Simulation of Langmuir Wave Collapse and Stimulated Raman Scatter in the Fluid-Kinetic Transition Regime
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award enables development and application of the Vlasov Multi-Dimensional (VMD) model to fundamental phenomena in non-equilibrium plasma dynamics. The VMD model takes advantage of directed plasma wave turbulence properties, encountered in laboratory and space environments, by rigorously joining particle and fluid aspects of plasma dynamics, something which has previously been unattainable. It had been thought that models which explicitly incorporate fluid dynamics must omit essential aspects of high temperature plasma dynamics. By showing that this is not necessarily the case, the VMD model advances our understanding, showing what is and what is not essential in standard plasma models.

VMD results in vastly more efficient simulation methods than afforded by traditional PIC ("particle in cell") methods. An early research goal is validation of the VMD model by comparison with results previously obtained by PIC simulations. Validation of the VMD model will allow its application to predicting the nonlinear evolution of plasma waves that naturally occur in high temperature plasma as found in the neighborhood of pulsars, in the earth's ionosphere, and, closer to earth, as they occur in the propagation of intense microwave and laser pulses in laboratory generated plasma. Of particular importance is the more accurate modeling of regime change. For example, how much power can be transmitted before plasma wave turbulence blocks laser propagation? Determination of laser intensity at regime change boundaries by PIC simulation may be obscured by unphysical noise. The VMD method is noise free, expanding the scope of plasma dynamics accessible by simulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for Award Number: 1004118

Collaborative research: Vlasov multi-dimensional simulation of Langmuir wave collapse and stimulated Raman scatter in the fluid-kinetic transition regime

 

Study of high-temperature plasma is extremely important for numerous applications ranging from the dynamics of stars to achieving a controllable laser fusion for energy production. The study of these phenomena represents enormous challenge  compare with everyday dynamics such as fluid flow because at each point of space we have to take into account the distribution of plasma particles over velocities while the usual fluid has only a single velocity at each spatial point. It means that for plasma we have to solve six dimensional problem over time with three spatial coordinates and three velocity coordinates. That equation in six dimensions is called the Vlasov equation. In addition, the enormous range of scales is involved in each of these six direction. While the dynamics of usual fluid still represent a big challenge for modern supercomputers, the plasma with six dimensions is nearly impossible to solve directly. E.g., taking very moderate number of 1000 points in each of six directions will require to resolve 10006=1018 = ten millions of billions points at each time step. This is well above all modern supercomputer capabilities. Figure 1 shows that at larger times smaller and smaller scales are produced so that 1000 points in each direction quickly become not sufficient. Figure 2 shows zoom-in from the  Figure 1 for time t=100 revealing even finer structures.

The main outcome and intellectual merit of our research is that we have developed a plasma dynamics model, the Vlasov Multi-Dimensional (VMD) model, which dramatically lessens the requirement of computational resources. We demonstrated that the major plasma properties within VMD are nearly identical to the Vlasov equation provided there is a dominant axis of power, such as when a laser beam propagates in plasma. A practical outcome is the relative ease of analysis and simulation of the VMD model compared with the Vlasov model. VMD results in vastly more efficient simulation methods than afforded by traditional PIC ("particle in cell") methods. Simplified plasma simulations that formerly required supercomputer  resources may now be performed on a  desktop computer. The VMD method is also noise free, expanding the scope of plasma dynamics accessible by simulation.

We used VMD to study new trapped electron filamentation instability which is important for laser fusion and results in non-uniform distribution of electrons in direction perpendicular to laser direction as shown in Figures 3 and 4.

The broader impact of our research is a dramatic improvement of the capabilities of high temperature simulations using VMD. We also trained a female postdoctoral researcher and 2 graduate students. One of graduate students has received PhD and is now a postdoctoral fellow at University of Arizona. We organized 1 scientific workshop and 8 sessions at scientific meetings. It allowed to improve skills of young researchers, train them in making scientific presentations and expose to the state of the art in research. PI Lushnikov developed and taught the graduate course on nonlinear waves at the University of New Mexico.
